cleaned_text: History of alternative medicine |This article is part of |[Alternative medicine](/wiki/Alternative_medicine) The history of alternative medicine refers to the history of a group of diverse medical practices that were collectively promoted as " [alternative medicine](/wiki/Alternative_medicine)" beginning in the 1970s, to the collection of individual histories of members of that group, or to the history of western medical practices that were labeled "irregular practices" by the western medical establishment. [[1]](#cite_note-CHBHAMA-1) [[2]](#cite_note-NCHAMA-2) [[3]](#cite_note-RRCAM-3) [[4]](#cite_note-ATRAMM-4) It includes of [integrative medicine](/wiki/Integrative_medicine). "Alternative medicine" is a loosely defined and very diverse set of products, practices, and theories that are perceived by its users to have the [healing](/wiki/Healing) effects of [medicine](/wiki/Medicine), but do not originate from [evidence](/wiki/Evidence) gathered using the [scientific method](/wiki/Scientific_method), [[10]](#cite_note-WebMD2014-10) [[11]](#cite_note-NCCIH-11) or are contradicted or established science. [[4]](#cite_note-ATRAMM-4) [[12]](#cite_note-AMCER-12) [[13]](#cite_note-Hines_Sampson_Coulter_Sagan-13) "Biomedicine" is that part practice](/wiki/Clinical_practice), using scientific methods to establish the effectiveness of that practice. Much of what is now categorized as alternative medicine was developed as independent, complete medical systems, was developed long before biomedicine and use of scientific methods, and was developed in relatively isolated regions of the world where there was little or no medical contact with pre-scientific western medicine, or with each other's systems. Examples are [Traditional Chinese medicine](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_medicine), European [humoral theory](/wiki/Humoral_theory) and the [Ayurvedic medicine](/wiki/Ayurvedic_medicine) of [India](/wiki/India). Other alternative medicine practices, such as [homeopathy](/wiki/Homeopathy), were developed in western Europe and in opposition to western medicine, at a time when western medicine was based on unscientific theories that were dogmatically imposed by western religious authorities. Homeopathy was developed prior to discovery of the basic principles of [chemistry](/wiki/Chemistry), which proved homeopathic remedies contained nothing but water. But homeopathy, with its remedies made of water, was harmless compared to the unscientific and dangerous orthodox western medicine practiced at that time, which included use of [toxins](/wiki/Toxin) and [draining of blood](/wiki/Bloodletting), often resulting in permanent disfigurement or death. [[1]](#cite_note-CHBHAMA-1) Other alternative practices such as [chiropractic](/wiki/Chiropractic) and [osteopathy](/wiki/Osteopathy), were developed in the United States at a time that western medicine was beginning to incorporate scientific methods and theories, but the biomedical model was not yet fully established. Practices such as chiropractic and osteopathy, each considered to be irregular by the medical establishment, also opposed each other, both rhetorically and politically with licensing legislation. Osteopathic practitioners added the courses and training of biomedicine to their licensing, and licensed [Doctor of Osteopathic Medicine](/wiki/Doctor_of_Osteopathic_Medicine) holders began diminishing use of the unscientific origins of the field, and without the original practices and theories, [Osteopathic medicine in the United States](/wiki/Osteopathic_medicine_in_the_United_States) is now considered the same as biomedicine. Until the 1970s, western practitioners that were not part of the medical establishment were referred to "irregular practitioners", and were dismissed by the medical establishment as unscientific or [quackery](/wiki/Quackery). [[1]](#cite_note-CHBHAMA-1) Irregular practice became increasingly marginalized as quackery and fraud, as western medicine increasingly incorporated scientific methods and discoveries, and had a corresponding increase in success of its treatments. In the 1970s, irregular practices were grouped with traditional practices of nonwestern cultures and with other unproven or disproven practices that were not part of biomedicine, with the group promoted as being "alternative medicine". Following the [counterculture movement](/wiki/Counterculture_movement) of the 1960s, misleading marketing campaigns promoting "alternative medicine" as being an effective "alternative" to biomedicine, and with changing social attitudes about not using chemicals, challenging the establishment and authority of any kind, sensitivity to giving equal measure to values and beliefs of other cultures and their practices through [cultural relativism](/wiki/Cultural_relativism), adding [postmodernism](/wiki/Postmodernism) and [deconstructivism](/wiki/Deconstructivism) to ways of thinking about science and its deficiencies, and with growing frustration and desperation by patients about limitations and side effects of [evidence-based medicine](/wiki/Evidence-based_medicine), use of alternative medicine in the west began to rise, then had explosive growth beginning in the 1990s, when senior level political figures began promoting alternative medicine, and began diverting government medical research funds into research of alternative, complementary, and integrative concept of alternative medicine is problematic as it cannot exist autonomously as an object of study in its own right but must always be defined in relation to a non-static and transient medical orthodoxy. [[17]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBlécourtUsborne1999a284-17) It also divides medicine into two realms, a medical mainstream and fringe, which, in privileging [orthodoxy](/wiki/Orthodoxy), presents difficulties in constructing an historical analysis independent of the often biased and polemical views of regular medical practitioners. [[18]](#cite_note-18) The description of non-conventional medicine as alternative reinforces both its marginality and the centrality of official medicine. [[19]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBradley200219-19) Although more neutral than either pejorative or promotional designations such as " [quackery](/wiki/Quackery)" or " [natural medicine](/wiki/Naturopathy)", "unorthodox" define their object against the standard of conventional biomedicine, [[20]](#cite_note-20) entail particular perspectives and judgements, often carry moral overtones, and can be inaccurate. [[21]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJütte1999343-21) Conventional medical practitioners in the West have, since the nineteenth century, used some of these and similar terms as a means of defining the [boundary](/wiki/Boundary-work) of "legitimate" medicine, marking the division between that which is [scientific](/wiki/Science) and that which is not. [[22]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJütte200112-22) The definition of mainstream medicine, generally understood to refer to a system of [licensed medicine](/wiki/Medical_license) which enjoys state and legal protection in a jurisdiction, [[n 1]](#cite_note-24) is also highly specific to time and place. In countries such as India and China [traditional systems of medicine](/wiki/Traditional_medicine), in conjunction with Western [biomedical science](/wiki/Healthcare_science), may be considered conventional and mainstream. [[21]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJütte1999343-21) The shifting nature of these terms is underlined by recent efforts to demarcate between alternative treatments on the basis of [efficacy](/wiki/Efficacy) and safety and to amalgamate those therapies with scientifically adjudged value into complementary medicine as a pluralistic adjunct to conventional practice. [[n 2]](#cite_note-26) This would introduce a new line of division based upon medical validity. [[25]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTERamsey1999287-27) Before the "fringe"[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_alternative_medicine&action=edit§ion=2)] Prior to the nineteenth century European medical training and practice was ostensibly self-regulated through a variety of antique corporations, guilds or [colleges](/wiki/Medical_college). [[26]](#cite_note-28) Among regular practitioners, university trained physicians formed a medical elite while provincial [surgeons](/wiki/Surgeon) and [apothecaries](/wiki/Apothecary), who learnt their art through [apprenticeship](/wiki/Apprenticeship), made up the lesser ranks. [[27]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPorter1999287-29) In [Old Regime France](/wiki/Early_Modern_France), licenses for medical practitioners were granted by the [medical faculties](/wiki/Medical_school) of the major universities, such as the Paris Faculty of Medicine. Access was restricted and successful candidates, amongst other requirements, had to pass examinations and pay regular fees. [[27]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPorter1999287-29) In the [Austrian Empire](/wiki/Austrian_Empire) medical licences were granted by the Universities of Prague and Vienna. [[28]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPorter1999288-30) Amongst the [German states](/wiki/Kleinstaaterei) the top physicians were academically qualified and typically attached to medical colleges associated with the royal court. [[28]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPorter1999288-30) The theories and practices included the science of [anatomy](/wiki/Anatomy) and that the blood circulated by a pumping heart, and contained some empirically gained information on progression of disease and about surgery, but were otherwise unscientific, and were almost entirely ineffective and dangerous. Outside of these formal medical structures there were myriad other medical practitioners, often termed irregulars, plying a range of services and goods. [[29]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPickstone2006264-31) The eighteenth-century medical marketplace, a period often referred to as the "Golden Age of quackery", [[30]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPorter1999284-32) [[n 3]](#cite_note-34) was a highly pluralistic one that lacked a well-defined and policed division between "conventional" and "unconventional" medical practitioners. [[32]](#cite_note-35) In much of continental Europe legal remedies served to control at least the most egregious forms of "irregular" medical practice but the medical market in both Britain and American was less restrained through regulation. [[33]](#cite_note-36) Quackery in the period prior to modern medical [professionalisation](/wiki/Professionalization) should not be considered equivalent to alternative medicine as those commonly deemed quacks were not peripheral figures by default nor did they necessarily promote oppositional and alternative medical systems. Indeed, the charge of 'quackery', which might allege medical incompetence, avarice or fraud, was levelled quite indiscriminately across the varied classes of medical practitioners be they regular medics, such as the hierarchical, corporate classes of physicians, surgeons and apothecaries in England, or irregulars such as [nostrum](/wiki/Patent_medicine) mongers, [bonesetters](/wiki/Bonesetter) and local wise-women. [[34]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPorter19882-3-37) Commonly, however, quackery was associated with a growing medical entrepreneurship amongst both regular and irregular practitioners in the provision of goods and services along with associated techniques of advertisement and self-promotion in the medical marketplace. [[35]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPorter19883-38) The constituent features of the medical marketplace during the eighteenth century were the development of medical [consumerism](/wiki/Consumerism) and a high degree of patient power and choice in the selection of treatments, the limited efficacy of available medical therapies, [[36]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPorter1999266-39) and the absence of both medical professionalisation and enforced regulation of the market. [[35]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPorter19883-38) Medical professionalisation[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_alternative_medicine&action=edit§ion=3)] In the late eighteenth and nineteenth centuries regular and irregular medical practitioners became more clearly differentiated throughout much of Europe. [[37]](#cite_note-40) In part, this was achieved through processes of state-sanctioned medical regulation. [[38]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPickstone2006262-41) The different types of regulatory medical markets created across nineteenth-century Europe and America reflected differing historical patterns of [state formation](/wiki/State_formation). [[38]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPickstone2006262-41) Where states had traditionally enjoyed strong, centralised power, such as in the German states, government more easily assumed control of the medical regulation. [[38]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPickstone2006262-41) In states that had exercised weaker central power and adopted a [free-market](/wiki/Free_market) model, such as in Britain, government gradually assumed greater control over medical regulation as part of increasing state focus on issues of [public health](/wiki/Public_health). [[38]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPickstone2006262-41) This process was significantly complicated in Britain by the enduring existence of the historical medical colleges. [[38]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPickstone2006262-41) A similar process is observable in America from the 1870s but this was facilitated by the absence of medical corporations. [[38]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPickstone2006262-41) Throughout the nineteenth century, however, most Western states converged in the creation of legally delimited and semi-protected medical markets. [[38]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPickstone2006262-41) It is at this point that an "official" medicine, created in cooperation with the state and employing a scientific rhetoric of [legitimacy](/wiki/Legitimation), emerges as a recognisable entity and that the concept of alternative medicine as a historical category becomes tenable. [[39]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTERamsey1999290-42) France provides perhaps one of the earliest examples of the emergence of a state-sanctioned medical orthodoxy - and hence also of the conditions for the development of forms of alternative medicine - the beginnings of which can be traced to the late eighteenth century. [[40]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTERamsey1999297-43) In addition to the traditional French medical faculties and the complex hierarchies of practitioners over which they presided, the state increasingly supported new institutions, such as the Société Royale de Médecine (Royal Society of Medicine) which received its royal charter in 1778, that played a role in policing medical practice and the sale of medical nostrums. [[41]](#cite_note-44) This system was radically transformed during the early phases of the [French Revolution](/wiki/French_Revolution) when both the traditional faculties and the new institutions under royal sponsorship were removed and an entirely unregulated medical market was created. [[42]](#cite_note-Pi267Po352-45) This anarchic situation was reformed under the exigencies of war when in 1793 the state established national control over medical education; under [Napoleon](/wiki/Napoleon) in 1803 state-control was extended over the licensing of medical practitioners. [[42]](#cite_note-Pi267Po352-45) This latter reform introduced a new hierarchical division between practitioners in the creation of a medical élite of [graduate physicians and surgeons](/wiki/Doctor_of_Medicine), who were at liberty to practice throughout the state, and the lowly officiers de santé who received less training, could only offer their services to the poor, and were restricted in where they could practice. [[43]](#cite_note-46) This national system of medical regulation under state-control, exported to regions of [Napoleonic conquest](/wiki/First_French_Empire) such as Italy, the [Rhineland](/wiki/Rhineland) and the Netherlands, [[44]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPorter1999353-47) became paradigmatic in the West and in countries adopting western medical systems. [[45]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTERamsey1999298-48) While offering state protection to licensed doctors and establishing a medical [monopoly](/wiki/Monopoly) in principal it did not, however, remove competition from irregular practitioners. [[46]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPickstone2006268-49) Nineteenth-century non-conventional medicine[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_alternative_medicine&action=edit§ion=4)] From the late eighteenth century and more robustly from the mid-nineteenth century a number of non-conventional medical systems developed in the West which proposed oppositional medical systems, criticised orthodox medical practitioners, emphasised patient-centredness, and offered substitutes for the treatments offered by the medical mainstream. [[47]](#cite_note-50) While neither the medical marketplace nor irregular practitioners disappeared during the nineteenth century, the proponents of alternative medical systems largely differed from the entrepreneurial quacks of the previous century in eschewing showy self-promotion and instead adopting a more sober and serious self-presentation. [[48]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELoudon1987116-17-51) The relationship between medical orthodoxy and heterodoxy was complex, both categories contained considerably variety, were subject to substantial change throughout the period, and the divisions between the two were frequently blurred. [[49]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBradley200219-21-52) Many alternative notions grew out of the [Lebensreform](/wiki/Lebensreform) movement, which emphasized the goodness of nature, the harms to society, people, and to nature caused by industrialization, the importance of the whole person, body and mind, the power of the sun, and the goodness of "the old ways". [[50]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams200740-53) [[51]](#cite_note-54) [[52]](#cite_note-55) [[53]](#cite_note-fitz-56) [[54]](#cite_note-57) The variety of alternative medical systems which developed during this period can be approximately categorised according to the form of treatment advocated. These were: those employing spiritual or psychological therapies, such as [hypnosis](/wiki/Hypnosis) ( [mesmerism](/wiki/Mesmerism)); nutritional therapies based upon special diets, such as medical botany; drug and biological therapies such as [homeopathy](/wiki/Homeopathy) and [hydrotherapy](/wiki/Hydrotherapy); and, manipulative physical therapies such as [osteopathy](/wiki/Osteopathy) and [chiropractic](/wiki/Chiropractic) massage. [[55]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJütte200115-58) Non-conventional medicine might define health in terms of concepts of balance and harmony or espouse [vitalistic](/wiki/Vitalism) doctrines of the body. Illness could be understood as due to the accretion of bodily [toxins](/wiki/Toxin) and impurities, to result from magical, [spiritual](/wiki/Spiritualism), or supernatural causes, or as arising from energy blockages in the body such that healing actions might constitute energy transfer from practitioner to patient. [[55]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJütte200115-58) Mesmerism[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_alternative_medicine&action=edit§ion=5)] Mesmerism is the medical system proposed in the late eighteenth century by the Viennese-trained physician, [Franz Anton Mesmer](/wiki/Franz_Mesmer) (1734-1815), for whom it is named. [[56]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBivins200780-59) The basis of this doctrine was Mesmer's claimed discovery of a new aetherial fluid, [animal magnetism](/wiki/Animal_magnetism), which, he contended, permeated the universe and the bodies of all animate beings and whose proper balance was fundamental to health and disease. [[57]](#cite_note-60) Animal magnetism was but one of series of postulated subtle fluids and substances, such as [caloric](/wiki/Caloric_theory), [phlogiston](/wiki/Phlogiston_theory), [magnetism](/wiki/Magnetism), and [electricity](/wiki/History_of_electromagnetic_theory), which then suffused the scientific literature. [[58]](#cite_note-61) It also reflected Mesmer's doctoral thesis, De Planatarum Influxu ("On the Influence of the Planets"), which had investigated the impact of the gravitational effect of [planetary movements](/wiki/Orbit) on fluid-filled bodily tissues. [[59]](#cite_note-62) His focus on magnetism and the therapeutic potential of [magnets](/wiki/Magnet) was derived from his reading of [Paracelsus](/wiki/Paracelsus), [Athanasius Kircher](/wiki/Athanasius_Kircher) and [Johannes Baptista van Helmont](/wiki/Johannes_Baptista_van_Helmont). [[60]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchlun200730-63) The immediate impetus for his medical speculation, however, derived from his treatment of a patient, Franzisca Oesterlin, who suffered from episodic seizures and [convulsions](/wiki/Convulsion) which induced vomiting, fainting, temporary blindness and paralysis. His cure consisted of placing magnets upon her body which consistently produced convulsive episodes and a subsequent diminution of symptoms. [[61]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPorter1999285-64) According to Mesmer, the logic of this cure suggested that health was dependent upon the uninterrupted flow of a putative magnetic fluid and that ill health was consequent to its blockage. His treatment methods claimed to resolve this by either directly transferring his own superabundant and naturally occurring animal magnetism to his patients by touch or through the transmission of these energies from magnetic objects. [[62]](#cite_note-65) By 1775 Mesmer's Austrian practice was prospering and he Schrieben über die Magnetkur an einen auswärtigen Arzt which first outlined his thesis of animal magnetism. [[63]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchlun200735-66) In 1778, however, he became embroiled in a scandal resulting from his treatment of a young, blind patient who was connected to the Viennese court and relocated to Paris where he established a medical salon, "The Society of Harmony", for the treatment of patients. [[64]](#cite_note-67) Recruiting from a client-base drawn predominantly from society women of the middle- and upper-classes, Mesmer held group séances at his salubrious salon-clinic which was physically dominated by a large, lidded, wooden tank, known as the baquet, containing iron, glass and other material that Mesmer had magnetized and which was filled with "magnetized water". [[65]](#cite_note-68) At these sessions patients were enjoined to take hold of the metal rods emanating from the tub which acted as a reservoir for the animal magnetism derived from Mesmer and his clients. [[66]](#cite_note-69) Mesmer, through the apparent force of his will - not infrequently assisted by an intense gaze or the administration of his wand - would then direct these energies into the afflicted bodies of his patients seeking to provoke either a "crisis" or a trance-like state; outcomes which he believed essential for healing to occur. [[67]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBivins200781-70) Patient proclamations of cure ensured that Mesmer enjoyed considerable and fashionable success in late-eighteenth-century Paris where he occasioned something of a sensation and a scandal. [[67]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBivins200781-70) Popular caricature of mesmerism emphasised the eroticised nature of the treatment as spectacle: "Here the physician in a coat of lilac or purple, on which the most brilliant flowers have been painted in needlework, speaks most consolingly to his patients: his arms softly enfolding her sustain her in her spasms, and his tender burning eye expresses his desire to comfort her". [[68]](#cite_note-71) Responding chiefly to the hint of sexual impropriety and political radicalism imbuing these séances, in 1784 mesmerism was subject to a commission of inquiry by a royal-appointed scientific panel of the prestigious French Académie de Médicine. [[69]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBivins200782-72) [[n 4]](#cite_note-75) Its findings were that animal magnetism had no basis in fact and that Mesmer's cures had been achieved through the power of [suggestion](/wiki/Suggestion). [[72]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGevitz1997620-76) The commission's report, if damaging to the personal status of Mesmer and to the professional ambitions of those faculty physicians who had adopted mesmeric practices, [[n 5]](#cite_note-77) did little to hinder the diffusion of the doctrine of animal magnetism. [[69]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBivins200782-72) In England mesmerism was championed by [John Elliotson](/wiki/John_Elliotson), Professor of Practical Medicine at [University College London](/wiki/University_College_London) and the founder and president of the London Phrenological Society. [[73]](#cite_note-78) A prominent and progressive orthodox physician, he was President of the [Medico-Chirugical Society of London](/wiki/Medical_and_Chirurgical_Society_of_London) and an early adopter of the [stethoscope](/wiki/Stethoscope#history) in English medical practice. [[74]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJacyna200621-22-79) He had been introduced to mesmerism in the summer of 1837 by the French physician and former student of Mesmer, Dupotet, who is credited as the most significant cross-channel influence on the development of mesmerism in England. [[75]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchlun200748-49-80) Elliotson believed that animal magnetism provided the basis for a consideration of the mind and will in material terms thus allowing for their study as medical objects. [[76]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBivins200784-81) Initially supported by [The Lancet](/wiki/The_Lancet), a reformist medical journal, [[77]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchlun200750-82) he contrived to demonstrate the scientific properties of animal magnetism as a physiological process on the predominantly female charity patients under his care in the University College Hospital. [[76]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBivins200784-81) Working-class patients were preferred as experimental subjects to exhibit the physical properties of mesmerism on the nervous system as, being purportedly more animalistic and machine-like than their social superiors, their personal characteristics were deemed less likely to interfere with the experimental process. [[78]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWinter1998a62-83) He sought to reduce his subjects to the status of mechanical automata claiming that he could, through the properties of animal magnetism and the pacifying altered states of consciousness which it induced, "play" their brains as if they were musical instruments. [[79]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWinter1998a62-63-84) Two Irish-born charity patients, the adolescent O'Key sisters, emerged as particularly important to Elliotson's increasingly popular and public demonstrations of mesmeric treatment. Initially, his magnetising practices were used to treat the sisters' shared diagnosis of hysteria and epilepsy in controlling or curtailing their convulsive episodes. By the autumn of 1837 Elliotson had ceased to treat the O'Keys merely as suitable objects for cure and instead sought to mobilise them as diagnostic instruments. [[80]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchlun200751-85) When in states of mesmeric entrancement the O'Key sisters, due to the apparent increased sensitization of their nervous system and sensory apparatus, behaved as if they had the ability to see through solid objects, including the human body, and thus aid in medical diagnosis. As their fame rivalled that of Elliotson, however, the O'Keys behaved less like human diagnostic machines and became increasingly intransigent to medical authority and appropriated to themselves the power to examine, diagnose, prescribe treatment and provide a prognosis. [[81]](#cite_note-86) The emergence of this threat to medical mastery in the form of a pair of working-class, teenage girls without medical training aroused general disquiet amongst the medical establishment and cost Elliotson one of his early and influential supporters, the leading proponent of medical reform, [Thomas Wakley](/wiki/Thomas_Wakley). [[82]](#cite_note-87) Wakley, the editor of The Lancet, had initially hoped that Elliotson's scientific experiments with animal magnetism might further the agenda of medical reform in bolstering the authority of the profession through the production of scientific truth and, equally importantly in a period when the power-relations between doctors and patients were being redefined, quiescent patient bodies. [[83]](#cite_note-88) Perturbed by the O'Key's provocative displays, Wakely convinced Elliotson to submit his mesmeric practice to a trial in August 1838 before a jury of ten gentlemen during which he accused the sisters of fraud and his colleague of gullibility. [[84]](#cite_note-89) Following a series of complaints issued to the Medical Committee of University College Hospital they elected to discharge the O'Keys along with other mesmeric subjects in the hospital and Elliotson resigned his post in protest. [[85]](#cite_note-90) This set-back, while excluding Elliotson from the medical establishment, ended neither his mesmeric career nor the career of mesmerism in England. From 1842 he became an advocate of [phreno-mesmerism](/wiki/Royal_Commission_on_Animal_Magnetism#Phreno-magnetism) - an approach that amalgamated the tenets of [phrenology](/wiki/Phrenology) with animal magnetism and that led to a split in the Phrenological Society. [[86]](#cite_note-harvnb|Winter|1998a|p=154-91) [[87]](#cite_note-92) The following year he founded, together with the physician and then President of the Phrenological Society, [William Collins Engledue](/wiki/William_Collins_Engledue), [[88]](#cite_note-93) the principal journal on animal magnetism entitled [The Zoist: A Journal of Cerebral Physiology and Mesmerism and their Application to Human Welfare](/wiki/The_Zoist), a quarterly publication which remained in print until its fifty-second issue in January 1856. [[86]](#cite_note-harvnb|Winter|1998a|p=154-91) [[89]](#cite_note-94) Mesmeric societies, frequently patronised by those among the scientific and social elite were established in many major population centres in Britain from the 1840s onwards. [[90]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWinter1998a156-95) Some sufficiently endowed societies, such as those in London, Bristol and Dublin, Ireland, supported mesmeric infirmaries with permanent mesmeric practitioners in their employ. [[90]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWinter1998a156-95) Due to the competing rise of spiritualism and psychic research by the mid-1860s these mesmeric infirmaries had closed. [[90]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWinter1998a156-95) The 1840s in Britain also witnessed a deluge of travelling magnetisers who put on public shows for paying audiences to demonstrate their craft. [[91]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWinter1998b32-96) These mesmeric theatres, intended in part as a means of soliciting profitable private clientele, functioned as public fora for debate between skeptics and believers as to whether the performances were genuine or constituted fraud. [[91]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWinter1998b32-96) In order to establish that the loss of sensation under mesmeric trance was real, these itinerant mesmerists indulged in often quite violent methods - including discharging firearms close to the ears of mesmerised subjects, pricking them with needles, putting acid on their skin and knives beneath their fingernails. [[91]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWinter1998b32-96) Such displays of the anaesthetic qualities of mesmerism inspired some medical practitioners to attempt surgery on subjects under the spell of magnetism. [[92]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWinter1998b32-33-97) In France, the first major operation of this kind had been trialled, apparently successfully, as early as 1828 during a mastectomy procedure. [[93]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWinter1998b34-98) In Britain the first significant surgical procedure undertaken on a patient while mesmerised occurred in 1842 when James Wombell, a labourer from Nottingham, had his leg amputated. [[94]](#cite_note-99) Having been mesmerised for several days prior to the operation by a barrister named William Topham, Wombell exhibited no signs of pain during the operation and reported afterwards that the surgery had been painless. [[95]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWinter1998b33-100) This account was disputed by many in the medical establishment who held that Wombell had fraudulently concealed the pain of the amputation both during and after the procedure. [[96]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWinter1998b-101) Undeterred, in 1843 Elliotson continued to advocate for the use of animal magnetism in surgery publishing Numerous Cases of Surgical Operation without Pain in the Mesmeric State. [[97]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrabtree2008569-102) This marked the beginning of a campaign by London mesmerists to gain a foothold for the practice within British hospitals by convincing both doctors and the general public of the value of surgical mesmerism. [[98]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWinter2004103-04-103) Mesmeric surgery enjoyed considerable success in the years from 1842 to 1846 and colonial India emerged as a particular stronghold of the practice; word of its success was propagated in Britain through the Zoist and the publication in 1846 of Mesmerism in India and its Practical Application in Surgery and Medicine by James Esdaile, a Scottish surgeon with the East India Company and the chief proponent of animal magnetism in the subcontinent. [[99]](#cite_note-104) Although a few surgeons and dentists had undertaken fitful experiments with anaesthetic substances in the preceding years, it was only in 1846 that use of ether in surgery was popularised amongst orthodox medical practitioners. [[93]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWinter1998b34-98) This was despite the fact that the desensitising effects of widely available chemicals like ether and nitrous oxide were commonly known and had formed part of public and scientific displays over the previous half-century.
